questions.question: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by
questions.explanation: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy.

questions.question: An obese woman with dysmenorrhea and irregular periods is diagnosed with dystocia dystrophia syndrome. What type of pelvis is seen here?
questions.explanation: In dystocia dystrophia syndrome, an android pelvis is seen. Dystocia dystrophia syndrome: The patient is stockily built with a bull neck, broad shoulders, and short thighs. She is obese with a male distribution of hair. Subfertile, with dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or irregular periods. There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity. The pelvis is of the android type. The occipito-posterior position is common. During labor, there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia, leading to difficult instrumental delivery or cesarean section. There is a chance of lactation failure.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the anthropoid pelvis?
questions.explanation: The anthropoid pelvis has straight side walls, not convergent side walls. Given below are the differences between various types of pelvis as per the Caldwell-Moloy classification. Shape: Sacral angle - Gynecoid: Round, Anthropoid: Anteroposteriorly oval, Android: Triangular/Heart-shaped, Platypelloid: Transversely oval/Flat bowl-shaped. Sacral angle: >90°, >90°, <90°, >90°. Side walls: Straight or slightly divergent, Straight or divergent, Convergent, Divergent. Ischial spines: Not prominent, Not prominent, Prominent, Not prominent. Subpubic angle: Slightly narrow, Narrow, Very wide (>90°), Wide (85°). Fetal position: Engaging diameter - Occipitolateral, Oblique occipitoanterior, Transverse/oblique, Direct occipitoanterior/occipitoposterior. Anteroposterior: Occipitolateral, Oblique occipitolateral, e occipitoposterior, Transverse oblique, Transverse. Delivery: Gynecoid - No difficulty, Anthropoid - Face-to-pubis - most common, Android - Deep transverse arrest is common. Difficult delivery with an increased chance of perineal injuries, Platypelloid - No difficulty. Caldwell-Moloy classification of the types of the pelvis: PAGynecoid, AAnthropoid, Intermediates, APlatypelloid, OMARROW, Android.

questions.question: A 28-year-old term primigravida gave birth to a male baby by face to pubis delivery. Which type of pelvis is this mode of delivery commonly seen with?
questions.explanation: Face to pubis delivery is most commonly associated with anthropoid pelvis. As the anthropoid pelvis is wider posteriorly, the fetal occiput occupies the posterior segment of the pelvis. Thus, the fetus is present in the occipitoposterior position, which leads to a high chance of face-to-pubis delivery. Caldwell-Moloy classification of the types of the pelvis: Anthropoid, Intermediate, Gynecoid, Platypelloid, and Android.

questions.question: An obstetrician performing clinical pelvimetry finds that the smallest transverse diameter is 8 cm. Which of the following parameters has she assessed?
questions.explanation: The interspinous diameter is the smallest transverse pelvic diameter. The interspinous diameter or bispinous diameter is measured in the mid pelvis. It is the distance between the tips of two ischial spines. Normally, it is 10-10.5 cm. It is useful in predicting obstructed labor. If the interspinous diameter is too small, the baby's head may get stuck at a higher station. Note: The obstetric conjugate is the smallest anteroposterior pelvic diameter, measuring 10 cm.

questions.question: During clinical pelvimetry, the obstetrician determines the diagonal conjugate to be X cm. What is the obstetric conjugate?
questions.explanation: The obstetric conjugate is X-2 cm, where X is the diagonal conjugate. Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis: • True conjugate or the anteroposterior diameter extends from the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 11 cm. • Obstetrical conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. It is normally 10 cm. It is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. • Diagonal conjugate is determined by measuring the distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 12 cm. It is measured clinically. Diameters of the pelvic inlet: Sacral promontory, True conjugate, Obstetrical conjugate, Diagonal conjugate, Symphysis pubis.

questions.question: A diabetic primigravida is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion. What should her obstetric conjugate be for a trial of labor to be conducted?
questions.explanation: In the given case scenario, a trial of labor or vaginal delivery can be allowed if the obstetric conjugate is 10 cm or more. The obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. Normally, it is 10 cm or more. The diagonal conjugate measures 12 cm and the true conjugate measures 11 cm. Clinically, only the diagonal conjugate is assessed by measuring the distance between the base of the examiner's fingers and the fingertip touching the sacral promontory. This determines the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. The obstetric conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. Note: Overt diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia during pregnancy. Thus, it may lead to cephalopelvic disproportion.

questions.question: Which of the following parameters cannot be viewed in lateral plate X-ray pelvimetry?
questions.explanation:
The bispinous diameter can be viewed in the anteroposterior view and not the lateral plate pelvimetry. X-ray pelvimetry is done using 3 views: 
   • Anteroposterior - Transverse diameter and bispinous diameter are determined. 
   • Lateral - Obstetric conjugate, sacral curve, and pelvic inclination are seen. 
   • Outlet - Outlet diameters are determined. 
   Note: CT pelvimetry is preferred over X-ray pelvimetry due to the lower dose of radiation delivered. 
   Given below are images of CT pelvimetry, anteroposterior and lateral views respectively. The marked diameters are as follows: 
   2 - Interspinous diameter 
   3 - Intertuberous diameter 
   4 - Obstetric conjugate 
   5 - Pelvic outlet

questions.question: A P1A1 woman with a history of obstructed labor is being evaluated for a contracted pelvis. A CT pelvis shows that both sacral alae are absent. What is the type of pelvis seen here?
questions.explanation: The type of pelvis seen here is Robert's pelvis. In it, the pelvis is transversely contracted and the alae on both sides are absent, and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones. Option A: In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum. Option C: Kyphotic pelvis occurs secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column, either following tuberculosis or rickets. Option D: In a rachitic pelvis, due to softening of bones, flattening of the pelvis occurs.

questions.question: A patient with a prolonged second stage of labor is referred to the district hospital. You suspect her to have a contracted pelvis. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.A: Transverse diameter of inlet is 10 cm
options.B: Anteroposterior diameter of inlet is 12 cm
options.C: Transverse diameter of inlet is 12 cm
options.D: Anteroposterior diameter of inlet is 14 cm

questions.explanation: To make a diagnosis of contracted pelvis, the transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet should be 10 cm. The pelvic inlet is considered to be contracted if: the greatest transverse diameter is < 12 cm or the shortest anteroposterior diameter is < 10 cm. The anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet are the true conjugate, diagonal conjugate, and obstetric conjugate. These extend between the sacral promontory and symphysis pubis. The obstetric conjugate is the shortest diameter, normally measuring 10 cm. The transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet is at a right angle to the obstetric conjugate. It extends between the linea terminalis on either side. Normally, the transverse diameter is about 13 cm.

questions.question: Which of the following is the smallest diameter of the fetal head?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, the bitemporal diameter is the smallest. It is the distance between the anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture and usually measures 8 cm. This is the smallest engaging diameter. Option A: The biparietal diameter is a transverse diameter between two parietal eminences, measuring 9.5 cm. Option B: The suboccipitofrontal diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 10 cm. Option C: The suboccipitobregmatic diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 9.5 cm. Note: The bimastoid diameter is a transverse diameter. It is the smallest diameter in the fetal skull at about 7.5 cm. However, it is not clinically relevant as it does not engage.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman in labor is referred to a tertiary care center. On PV examination, the resident notes that the fetus is in brow presentation, and the largest diameter of the fetal skull, 50, is engaged. Identify this diameter.
questions.explanation: In brow presentation, the mentovertical diameter is engaged, which is the longest diameter of the fetal skull. Normally, it measures 14 cm. The mentovertical diameter extends from the midpoint of the chin to the highest point on the sagittal suture. Engaging diameters of the fetal skull vary with the attitude of the fetal head as given below: Diameters - Attitude of the head: Suboccipitobregmatic - Complete flexion, Occipitofrontal - Incomplete flexion, Mento-vertical - Marked deflexion, Submentovertical - Partial extension, Submentobregmatic - Incomplete extension, and Mentovertical - Complete extension.

questions.question: A G6P5L5 woman presented to the casualty with abdominal pain. The PV examination findings are given below. What is the engaging diameter?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the engaging diameter is the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter. It is engaged when the fetus is in vertex presentation with an attitude of complete flexion of the head. The table given below shows the engaging diameter with each attitude of the fetal head. Diameters - Attitude of the head: Suboccipitobregmatic - Complete flexion, Suboccipito-frontal - Incomplete flexion, Occipitofrontal - Marked deflexion, Mento-vertical - Partial extension, Submentovertical - Incomplete extension, Submentobregmatic - Complete extension.

questions.question: How many fontanelles are present in a newborn?
questions.explanation:
Newborns have a total of 6 fontanelles. These are fibrous, membrane-covered gaps between cranial bones. The fontanelles seen in newborns are: 
   • Anterior fontanelle: 
   • It is also called bregma. 
   • Diameter ranges from 0.6-3.6 cm, with a mean of 2.1 cm. 
   • It completely closes by 24 months of age. 
   • Posterior fontanelle: 
   • It is also called lambda. 
   • Diameter ranges from 0.5-0.7 cm. 
   • It completely closes by 2 months of age. 
   • 2 sphenoid fontanelles 
   • 2 mastoid fontanelles 
   Note: A third fontanelle between the anterior and posterior fontanelles is associated with hypothyroidism and Down's syndrome. 
   Fontanelles of skull 
   Lateral view of skull 
   Posterior fontanelle closes by 2-3 months 
   Parietal bone 
   Mastoid fontanelle 
   Occipital bone 
   Anterior fontanelle closes by 18-24 months 
   Sphenoidal fontanelle 
   Temporal bone 
   closes by 2-3 months of age 
   MARROW 
   Frontal bone

questions.question: A 24-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by assisted forceps delivery. The next day, you note a swelling over the infant's head that is limited by suture lines. Which of the following is true regarding the swelling?

options.A: Tension in the swelling varies on crying

questions.explanation: In the given clinical picture, the swelling over the infant's head is likely to be a cephalhematoma. Infants with cephalohematomas are at a heightened risk of developing jaundice because as the blood breaks down, the levels of bilirubin increase. Cephalohematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone (subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone. It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12-24 h. The swelling is limited by the suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone. Option A: Tension in the swelling varies with crying in meningocele. Option C: Edematous fluid collects in caput succedaneum. Option D: Caput succedaneum may be present at birth.

questions.question: The pediatrician notices a diffuse, reddish scalp swelling in a newborn born by vacuum extraction. Which of the following is not a characteristic of this condition?

options.C: It does not disappear within 2-3 days.
options.D: It is a diffuse edematous swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.

questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of caput succedaneum, which disappears within 2-3 days. In vertex presentation, labor forces alter the shape of the fetal head. In prolonged labor, before complete cervical dilatation, the portion of the fetal scalp immediately over the cervical os becomes edematous. A swelling is formed due to the stagnation of fluid in the layers of the scalp beneath the girdle of contact. This is known as caput succedaneum. The swelling is diffuse, boggy, and not limited by the suture lines. It resolves spontaneously within 2-3 days after birth. It is a result of the static position of the head for a long period of time. Chignon is a type of artificial caput succedaneum, which is a swelling produced on the fetal head because of the scalp getting sucked into the cup during vacuum extraction.
